description:
Fresh dumplings, simple menu, delicious food!

Their dumplings are made fresh to order with the perfect skin to meat ratio. You can choose to have the dumplings without soup (14 pieces) or with soup (clear broth with 12 pieces). I prefer it with soup because it keeps the dumplings hot and juicy. The broth is clear and savory with seaweed, green onions and cilantro. Order the Shiitake Mushroom & Fish Dumpling, smooth in texture and delicious flavors. My 2nd favorite is the Pork & Three Delicacies Dumpling.

Shredded Pig Ear in Chili Oil - thinly sliced marinated pig ear, crunchy texture, and flavorful. This is a cold dish. 

Hot & Spicy Beef Tendons - also a cold dish, thinly sliced beef tendons with sliced white onions. Delicious!

Its a small location, sometimes there is a wait, sometime the service takes a little long, but I think its worth the wait considering how fresh the dumplings are.
author: Janny S.

description:
Dumplings are freshly wrapped. Skin is nice and thin, meat is fresh. Also tried the beef noodle soup and the broth was flavorful, but the noodles were alright. Recommend trying any of the dumplings, just depends on your preferred filling. I've tried the chicken and shiitake and fish and shiitake and both were good. I'd probably pass on ordering them in soup as the soup is nothing too amazing, it was like a plain seaweed soup.

Good addition to the area but it gets really busy and isn't a very big place.
author: Mary X.

description:
Dumplings are decent, but the Beef Noodles are the BOMB!!! 
My friends brought me here on a Friday night around 8pm. The 4 of us were seated after a short 10-minute wait. The restaurant is small but clean. You can see chinese ladies behind a glass window making fresh dumplings. My friends have been here a few times. They ordered the cucumber salad and tofu sticks for starters, beef noodle soup, and 3 different types dumplings- Shiitake mushroom & fish, celery & pork, and shrimp & 3 delicacies. Out of the dumplings, my favorite was the celery & pork, yea yea basic I know, but the other two tasted really bland to me. The shrimp and 3 delicacies was filled heavily with chives which I do not like. If I had known chives was one of the delicacies, I would have ordered something different. 

Now let's talk about the beef noodle soup!! It's so good, I highly recommend ordering it. We got it with mild spiciness, which was perfectly flavored and the noodles are nicely cooked. Honestly next time I go, I would skip the dumplings and order the beef noodles instead!
author: Valerie C.

description:
You know how sub-par service can really mess up your feelings about a place? That's kind of how I'm currently feeling about Yuanbao Jiaozi which is unfortunate because they make some truly delicious dumplings in my opinion.

Walked in during an off-hour and was able to get seated right away - there were only about 3 other tables at the time. We perused the short menu and opted for two plates of dumplings just to hold us over.

...5 minutes

...10 minutes

...20 minutes

Okay what's going on? Are they raising a pig for the pork or growing cabbage for these dumplings?

We wave down a waitress and she "checks" with the kitchen citing an additional 10 minutes was needed. At this point, I just have to raise my voice a bit - we're looking at 30 minutes for boiled dumplings? Are you kidding me? She then bargains with us - how about 5 minutes? Fine. Whatever. But then we watch another 3-4 plates come out none of which are ours. 

Unacceptable.

Cue us waving down second hostess who actually goes to check the tickets. She rifles through the pile and looks up with a shocked face...and repeats the process as if she had missed it the first time. Next thing you know, she walks to the kitchen and pulls out one of the ladies who typically makes the dumplings and immediately assigns her to make our dishes. She apologizes to us, citing a computer error....I guess that makes it okay?

By the time our dumplings arrive, we were very hangry to say the least.  2 plates of dumplings should have never taken 40 minutes to arrive. In fact, I'm also disappointed that they didn't even realize something was amiss before we did. I'm also not one to ask for free things but I honestly felt like a discount or a free appetizer was warranted in this case.

So as good as they were in technical skill and taste, it just didn't hit the spot at all.

Hopefully this was a one-off experience.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Came here after a long 3 days at OSL & it hit the spot!

Quiet and small restaurant in the Sunset neighborhood with delicious dumplings & beef noodle soup. Their small dishes are also great. We got the tofu salad and it was amazing! 

Nothing is more comforting than plates full of dumplings... and you'll get them here, freshly made in front of your eyes.

The service and ambiance are okay, so the food is really what you're coming for. They're open late!
author: Monica H.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while, but there's always been a long wait. Finally got to try this place on a Saturday during "linner" hours - got here around 430pm - and there was no wait! 

We were seated immediately and got to sit in front of the clear walls where we could see the workers freshly make the dumplings in front of us (kind of reminds me of Din Tai Fung!). 

We ordered the house special beef noodle soup (spicy), pork and napa cabbage dumplings, and shiitake mushroom and fish dumplings. We were not disappointed by any of these dishes! The beef noodle soup was very flavorful and not very spicy - they do have chili oil in case you want more spice! The noodles were cooked just right, and super easy to cut and divide among two people. Both dumplings were great, and very fresh! The mushroom and fish dumplings stood out to me the most though, you could really taste both flavors. You also get all the standard sauces (soy sauce, black vinegar, white vinegar, and chili oil) to make your perfect dipping sauce. I'll definitely come back and try more, if not all, of their dumplings! 

Parking in this area wasn't too hard! Although it was before 6pm and there were a good amount of meter spots left. 6pm and after, and Sundays could be a little harder to find parking though - just something to keep in mind!
author: Stacey Y.

description:
A new place for dumplings in the Sunset District of San Francisco! This new spot serves pretty authentic tasting, northern-style Chinese dumplings, and they offer a variety of different types. Coming from a northern Chinese family, I thought the appetizers were very authentic and the dumplings tasted similar to the ones I had tried while in China. 

We decided on the spicy pig ears appetizer, the shrimp and three delicacies boiled dumplings, and the beef noodle soup. The restaurant is small, and we luckily didn't have to wait for dinner at around 6pm on a Saturday night. The food, however, took a long time to arrive at the table,  and the service was somewhat lacking. The spicy pig ears were so full of  flavor, and I loved the spicy, garlic-onion aroma with the crunch of sesame seeds. The shrimp and three delicacies dumplings had a filling of shrimps, chives, and eggs and they were pretty good. There wasn't too much filling in the dumplings, but they were cooked perfectly. The beef noodle soup was also very good, but the noodles were a bit overcooked for me. 

I see this place becoming a popular spot in the future, and expect a line the next time I come. However, I did notice a lot of people order take out!
author: Sandra S.

description:
Home made authentic dumplings made from SCRATCH. just like my mama makes it! 
Delicious, great service and CLEAN bathroom! 
This is a must do if you are in the sunset area. Love!!!! Get the beef noodles!! Get everything! LOL the menu is super small so it's quite possible :)
author: Jo L.

description:
I came here with a friend on a Friday night around 7:30pm. Luckily the wait was only around 10 minutes!

We ordered the tofu skin salad, dumplings with pork with three delicacies, and dumplings with fish and shitake mushrooms. The tofu salad came out and the first thing we noticed was that it was pretty spicy! As we kept eating, it got spicier and spicier, but we enjoyed it. The dumplings came out together shortly after. Our favorite was the shitake mushroom & fish dumpling. The shitake was so flavorful and the fish was unexpectedly good. I've never had fish in a dumpling before, so it was different but yummy! The pork with three delicacies were just okay. We didn't really know what the three delicacies were, but we could see the scallions, lol!!

I like how you can mix your own sauce with their soy sauce, dark/white vinegar, and chili oil. I also like how you can watch the employees fold the dumplings through the little window! For now, the wait isn't as bad as other places, so this will definitely be a staple on my list of dumpling restaurants!
author: Tara A.

description:
My friend and I had the dumplings here, one of which was the fish and shiitake mushrooms which we had in a soup, and the other one was the pork and three delicacies, which we had dry. Honestly, besides the fact that they were affordable (14 dumplings for the dry, 12 dumplings for the soup at about $9 each), the food itself wasn't all that impressive.

The dumplings are freshly made (you can see them being made behind you), but they honestly taste like they were just boiled and then served quickly. I guess that's what dumplings are, but visually it left a lot to be desired.

Taste wise, the food was just mediocre. The meat didn't taste all that good on either dish, and dipping them didn't make it much better either. With so many dumpling places in the city, it's easy to get picky on such a popular item.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Don't deny me my dumplings.

As much as I love making dumplings, eating homemade dumplings sans the labor is just as, if not more, satisfying. I forget who had told me about this restaurant, but I couldn't deny my intrigue with the pinyin-based name. My friend and I both had a weekday free, so I asked her to drive us out to catch the opening hour in fear that the place would be crowded. Lo and behold, we were the only customers in the place at 11:30 on a Thursday.

As others state, the place is small, with five 4-seaters and four 2-seaters. Din Tai Fung-style, you can watch the chefs make dumplings from behind a glass panel. Jasmine tea is $1 per person and consists of tea bags and hot water from a Zojirushi water boiler in the back (not self-serve). There are 7 dumpling varieties, each order costing $8.99. An order of dumplings itself comes with 14, whereas an order of dumplings in soup comes with 11 or 12 dumplings. We opted for a plate of the celery and pork dumplings, which were tasty and not overpowered by the celery. We also ordered the $4.99 tofu skin stick salad and the $10.99 house special beef noodles, non-spicy. I was happy with the quantity of tender beef, but we both found the noodles in the beef noodle soup to be way too soggy, as if they had been boiled for too long. Would not get again.

Other reviewers mention that $9 for 14 dumplings is steep. For some skewed perspective (skewed because prices are from 2016), Shanghai Dumpling King sells 10 dumplings for $5.75, and Kingdom of Dumpling prices 12 pieces at $6.95. So, yes, 14 dumplings for $9 is a $1 more according to this linear equation, but it's not atrocious. My taste buds aren't picky enough to prefer one store's dumplings over another's, and, honestly, I can't think of a dumpling I've had that I haven't liked. So, if you happen to be nearby and are looking for some decent dumps, Yuanbao Jiaozi is solid.
author: Adele F.

description:
Pretty good overall. They have a varied selection of dumplings, which you can either get steamed or in a soup. They have the standard pork and cabbage dumplings, in addition to some that I haven't commonly seen on standard dumpling menus (e.g. shiitake mushroom and fish, green pepper and fish, etc.). We shared the cucumber salad, dumpling soup (with shiitake mushrooms and chicken), and steamed shrimp and zucchini dumplings. The cucumber salad was excellently flavored, with sesame oil, garlic, and cilantro. Yummmm. Definitely our favorite part of the meal. The dumpling soup was comforting and especially welcomed on a typical freezing summer day in SF (:. The broth was simple, fresh, and hit the spot. The steamed dumplings were just OK. They fell apart far too easily and the filling was a bit too 'eggy' for my taste. Also came with minimal shrimp, sadly. Meh. Would also be great if they offered fried dumplings. 

The restaurant is clean and you can see the chefs making your dumplings in the kitchen. Service was great. Wait was not too long on a holiday for a table of 3 (about 10 minutes). $8.99 for 12 steamed dumplings or dumpling soup = good price for the area. The tea served with the meal ($1 charge) was strong and delicious. Bonus points for *not* being cash only. Not my favorite dumpling place, but I'd go again if I was in the area (especially to try the spicy beef soup I was eyeing).
author: Tahmina N.

description:
I discovered this place after doing a quick 'hot and new restaurants' search near my area. I was craving dumplings so I decided to venture out of my comfort zone(frozen dumplings) to give it a try.

When I arrived, there were a few tables free but most I had a bad feeling when I walked in as there was only one waitress working but hey, that won't stop me from checking it out.

I ordered a few items I was craving which consisted of pig ears, garlic spicy cucumbers, and of course, dumplings! We ordered 3 different types of dumplings but made sure that at least one was with soup and the others without.

Food Highlight: Pork and 3 delicacies dumpling, spicy garlic cucumbers for added flavor and don't forget to create your own dipping sauce.
author: Rich L.

description:
This place opened in Feb and i've been meaning to try it.  I finally got the chance to try it last month and they did not disappoint.  They have a very limited menu, that had small appetizers, a noodle dish and a few dumplings for you to pick from.  For the dumplings, you can chose between the regular steam dumplings or the soup dumplings and the prices are the same.  

We ended up ordering the pork and three delicacies dumplings (steamed) and the house special beef noodles.  They make everything in house and you can watch them make it.  The noodles were so good and the beef soup wasn't salty.  Most places make it very salty, and i'm glad this turned out well.  The beef was also tender and had a lot of flavor.  The dumplings were so good! It was so sweet and juicy. and the skin wasn't thick, which I liked.  I can't wait to try their other dumplings.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Wow overrated. This place is always seemingly popular with a long wait and lines out the door. What I don't like is the hoards of people with nowhere to stand waiting around... 

Had mushroom and fish dumpling, pork and 3 delicacies -- seemed like it was filled with egg, possibly chives, green onions or some other kind of green veggie, and not sure what the 3rd delicacy is. Each order of dumplings is $8.99 and contains 12. With soup comes with a pretty plain broth. Dry dumplings would be better dipped with spicy chili oil paste. Also tried their marinated beef $6.99 and beef noodle soup $10.99 -- both were just average. 

Overall I think people like the "made fresh" concept and the other people who come are probably only here because they see a long line and assume there's great food. We will most likely not be returning.
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
Very limited seating but they accommodated our party of six.
Started with cucumber salad, spicy beef tendon main course spicy beef noodle soups, and three different order of dumplings all were Delicious.
Watch the ladies make the dumplings!!!
author: Wesley O.

description:
Flavorful yet light Chinese dumplings and tapas! If you're craving Chinese food minus all the greasy and heavy sauces, you will love this place! 

FOOD: 
Their menu is very straight forward and easy to choose from. They have variety of dumplings, 1 beef noodle soup and a small selection of tapas. We got: 
+ Cucumber salad $5: very refreshing with a small kick of sin chuan oil
+ Tofu skin salad $5: same taste as the cucumber salad, but with different texture of course
+ Beef Noodle Soup $10: the broth was flavorful without being too oily. The noodles were evenly shaped and chewy, but it came with less beef than I would have liked. 
+ Shrimp & 3 delicacies: shrimp, chive and other spices. This one was pretty good. The skin isn't too thick or too thin. The ratio of filling to skin is perfect. 
+ Chicken and Shiitake: This was our favorite!   

SERVICE: 
They only had one server/hostess when we were there. It was okay when only a couple of tables were full, but one server can be way under staff when people come all at once during rush hour. It took us awhile to get our bill because she was busy with other tables. But other than that, she was really friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. 

AMBIANCE: 
Like many trendy dumpling and dim sum places, you will get to watch the staff wrap the dumplings by hand through a glass wall. The shop itself isn't that big. They have about 9-10 tables that seat 2-6. They are located by Quicklys on Irving, so parking can definitely be a headache. 

Verdict: I would take my parents here to try there other dumplings!
author: Samantha F.

description:
Simple menu but thats alll you need here!!  We came with a group of 8 so we pretty much ordered most off the menu!  

Their appetizers are alll yummy! I will definitely go for the pig ears and beef tendons again! we got all the dumpling flavors but tbh I couldnt tell the difference lol I guess bc they are just all good 

It is transparent how the chefs are making dumplings right in front of us.  There are about 2 long tables and a couple small tables.  Not as spacious inside but the interior is very cute with a big Chinese painting!
author: Shuyi L.

description:
My friends introduced me to this gem in the Sunset and I'm so glad they did! The food is excellent for the quantity vs price, and they have a great selection of different types of dumplings. 

With all the dumplings, you have the choice of ordering them in soup or without. I highly recommend going with the soup (a tasty clear broth that doesn't distract from the flavor of the dumplings)! My favorite are the pork and celery dumplings. I'm surprised that I've never thought of that combination of filling before! I am also a huge fan of their beef noodle soup and their appetizers. 

From what I can tell, all orders are made to order, and it is so much fun watching the middle-aged ladies standing in a row at the counter behind the glass window. Kind of ding-tai-fung-esque! 

All in all, this is definitely the perfect place for a meal to warm your belly on a foggy Sunset summer day! Only gripe, they are closed on Tuesdays!!!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Yum!  Cheap, quality, dumplings :) 

Vibe: Quaint and peaceful. The soft piano music playing in the background made it zen like and super inviting for a Wednesday afternoon. 

Prices: $8.99 for 14 dumplings. Yep, 14. I did a double take because it's worth the money, and they aren't tiny either. 

Menu: Includes dumplings, small appetizers, and one type of noodle soup. 

I tried: 
-shrimp and 3 delicacy dumplings 
-mushroom and chicken dumplings with soup

I liked them both. There are about 8 different types, and you can order them dry or with soup. I recommend trying them alone, and then dipping them in sauce. They're great either way. 

Overall, I can really taste the authenticity here with the mandarin speaking workers and customers. There's a clear glass pane inside so you can see them making dumplings as you eat. 

Cash only if under $20! Otherwise they take card and Apple Pay.
author: Corinna T.

description:
The concept of FRESH made dumplings to order is awesome. I'm all about homemade dumplings! But execution? Not so good. 

I wanted to like this place SO much more than I did bc I love me some good dumplings. And man, they had SO many dumpling options I could eat here! All that seafood!!

We started off with three diff apps: (1) seaweed salad - uhhhh was this Costco bought? This was that Japanese seaweed salad you get at an Americanized restaurant. Not the szcheun type of seaweed salad you'd expect; (2) tofu skin salad - basically flavorless. No spice. No salt. No nothing; (3) cucumber salad - also flavorless. And sadly, the best of the three, but still not good. Also, the cucumber salad wasn't even chopped properly. The pieces weren't so much pieces as they were all stuck together by the skin! 

Then, dumplings. OKAY, those grandmas churning out dumplings made-to-order is impressive. We order fish and mushroom (boiled) and one of the shrimp ones (soup) to share. Few things. First of all, I'm no food inspector, but all the seafood was just left out while they were waiting to make the dumplings. Is that okay?? It's not at a refrigerated temp, which seemed a bit concerning. Secondly, the soup option wasn't so much a soup as it was boiled water with dumplings in it. ZERO flavor. And the worse part?! They don't even make their own sauce. Isn't that the best part of dumpling eating?! Or second best, behind the actual dumpling itself. 

Anyways, the fish one was better than the shrimp. But not by far. The food wasn't gross, by any means, but also wasn't good. For that price, I expected more. Kingdom of Dumpling has still got WAY better dumplings IMO. On top of all of this, service was pretty slow sooo 2 stars.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Date & Time:  Monday February 19, 2018 @ 1pm
Lunch Date:  The Husband 
Scene:  Couples & Groups in Sweaters, Burberry Scarves, Tights &  Boots
Decor:  Bright & Cheery; Dumpling Mural & Open-Kitchen w/ Glass Wall Looks-Out into Dining Area.  Chefs are Very Kind
Service:  Sweet, Courteous, Extremely Efficient Asian Girl
Devour:  Complimentary Peanuts & Radishes.  Spicy Beef Tendons, Soup Shrimp Dumplings w/ 3 Delicacies & Pork Dumplings.  Will Be Back for the Pan Fried Dumplings after their Soft-Opening Phase
Total:  $27.03
Note:  Happy President's Day Everybody!
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Stumbled upon this place last weekend accidentally and so glad we did! They had their soft opening and so in semi-testing mode, so probably limited quantity, but we thought it was great. Dumplings aren't made until you order, not even the wrap that they knead and flatten by hand one by one!

FOOD
-Pork and three delicacies- made fresh to order. Tasted super fresh and light. Good with and better without sauce IMO.
-Shredded pig ear in chili oil- yummy! Not spicy at all but light and flavorful at the same time.
-Tofu skin stick salad- the only semi-disappointment here bc the tofu sticks were too hard. If they were softer, it would have been much better
-peanuts and picked radishes- in the house while you wait for the food you ordered. Tasty!

SERVICE
Super friendly and very nice. A couple people came to order to-go but they still served them peanuts and rashes which I thought was generous. They came by to check on us a couple times throughout our meal and took away empty plates in a timely manner.

AMBIANCE/DECOR
Brightly lit and appears clean. Art on wall and menu also listed on top of counter/window where the chefs make the dumplings.

*Restroom is behind the window, which is a bit difficult to access Bc you have to walk thru their cashier and dumpling wrapping demonstration area. Also, there were trash bin, recycle bin, mop, as well as storage of paper napkins etc. in the restroom. Thought that wasn't very hygienic due to potential cross contamination. BUT since this is soft opening, I hope they find other space for paper napkins etc soon before they officially open for business!
author: Iris H.

description:
It's so refreshing to have an authentic Chinese place that is clean and pleasant. We came here on a Saturday for dinner and there was a short wait, about 10 mins. 

Between the 3 of us, we ordered:
- shredded seaweed 
- celery and peanut
- shiitake and fish dumplings
- zucchini and shrimp dumplings
- shrimp 3 delicacies dumplings: (chives taste great!)

I like how their dumplings are made in store, with thin wrappers, and very clean-taste. Actually the entire dining experience was pleasant and clean. I wasn't too impressed with the taste of the fillings, as in they taste good but not amazing. 

Bottom line: I'll eat here again if I'm in the area!
author: Wendy K.

description:
I'm giving a 3 star review only because they are understaffed and need more help. They only had one person working the dining room. That includes taking orders, bussing tables, seating people, closing checks, etc. I felt really bad for her. There were tables that just needed to be cleared and people waiting at least 15 minutes for them. There were others trying to pay their checks and that took forever too. I don't blame her, I think the restaurant should get someone else to work the dining room as well. 

Also, it was about 8pm and they already had run out of quite a few of their dumplings. Their menu was already limited. 

The food that we did go was really good. It's all freshly made and you can see the dumplings through the glass window. We ended up with the tofu stick salad, pork dumplings in soup and the chicken dumplings in soup. The soup tasted like water pretty much. I don't know if there's any broth in it. You got 12 dumplings per order, which was pretty decent, and they were all very good, especially with the chili they have on the table. 

I'd come back again if it looked empty or if there was more than one person working the dining room.
author: Julie L.

description:
By 7:30pm they were almost out of all dumplings on the menu.  They were even out of soda!

Tofu skin stick salad: ehh, I've had better
Pigs Ear: too sour, too much onion
Shiitake Mushroom & Fish Dumplings: good and worth ordering 

Service was horrible and slow in general.  The restaurant was half empty.

Here's what warrants the 2 stars - most items are gone and we order whatever is leftover, fine.  Another couple sits down next to us only minutes after and gets told the same, that just about everything is gone. She offers them the "secret menu" which is some sort of beef soup or beef noodle soup. why weren't we offered that?? And at this point, it should've been offered to anyone that walks in when only 2 out of 8 (dumping) items are available!
author: Angelica C.

description:
I love a small menu and fresh dumplings. The menu here is simple. It's like 10 different dumplings plates - all variations of either fish and mushrooms, celery and fish, shrimp and zucchini, pork and 3 delicacies. They come either steamed, in soup, or pan fried. Something was up, and they weren't offering pan fried so we only tried the steam versions and they were all great.  The appetizers are cold tasty things like cucumber, tendon, pig ears, tofu skin salad. We also ordered a beef noodle soup that was not on the main menu, but a side poster on the wall. Everything was definitely fresh and delicious. 
It was a soft opening, so service was a little slow and we didn't even get plates but overall it was great. Place is clean and you can see the food fresh - there's a window right there where you can watch the magic coming together.
author: Veronica L.

description: Came during their soft opening and the restaurant is very neat. They have an open kitchen so you can see what they put in the dumplings and how they make it. Waitress was nice so service was good. The dumplings have a very clean taste to it. The consistency of the skin is the perfect density and the filling is really flavorful. I also tried their solo noodle dish and it was delicious. Nothing too special, but it had a lot of spice and flavor.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Handmade made-to-order from scratch dumplings. In fact, after you order, you can literally watch a couple of Chinese grandmas in the window wrapping your dumplings to order. Super fresh and the taste definitely shows that. Does take a little bit longer for your order to come out, but again that's because it's literally made when you order.

The menu is pretty limited. Just a few varieties of dumplings, beef noodle soup, and a few cold appetizers. We ordered the cucumber salad and the beancurd skins which were both delicious. The beef noodle soup was a clearer, lighter broth but it was flavorful and delicious. Noodles were a bit generic though and too soft.

Of the dumplings, my highlights were the:
- Shrimp with Three Delicacies (P.S. the Three Delicacies are eggs, chives, and scallions)
- Shiitake Mushrooms with Fish

We arrived at 6 PM on a weekday and there was no wait but around 7:30 PM when we passed the restaurant again there was a pretty significant queue waiting outside. So, come early if you don't want to wait!
author: Jess Y.

description:
I love this place. My usual dishes are: beef noodle soup, pig ears, napa cabbage dumplings, fish dumplings, and shrimp dumplings. 

This place is amazing.
author: A C.

description: This newly discovered Chinese dumpling restaurant is my new favorite comfort food joint! Their mushroom and fish dumpling soup was very fresh, fluffy, and flavorful! Spicy beef noodle soup was very authentic and tasty!Shrimp and 3 delicacies dumpling soup was hearty and healthy. All dumplings were handmade to order, so we waited for a while before eating. We arrived at the restaurant 5 minutes after opening, and when we left the restaurant, there was already a short line outside.
author: Ting L.

description: The Beef Noodle Soup is one of the best I've had around town. Extremely flavorful and the noodles are the right balance of soft and sturdy. They have non-spicy and spicy versions (which isn't too spicy even if you think you can't hang). One of the unique benefits of this spot is getting to see the chefs at work through the glass window. They really make the dumplings and noodles all from scratch and it doesn't get more authentic and original than that. Enjoy!
author: Raymond W.

description: Love their FRESH auntie made dumplings w/ broth for a great price and it doesn't matter which meat you choose - price stays the same.
author: Kimi M.

description: I really wanted to love this place since it reminded me so much of Din Tai Fung with their dumpling makers on display. However, I was a bit letdown by how limited the menu was. When you flip over the menu to see the backside, you will be disappointed to find out it's blank. No rice. No vegetables. No potstickers. Pretty much nothing but dumplings. Speaking of the dumplings, while good, they could definitely use a bit more filling.
author: Charles L.

description:
Amazing find in the heart of Irving Street near the Golden Gate Park.

Authentic and serene and a nice peaceful yummy break from the busy of your vacation. It is also full of locals so you know it's good food.
author: Lois S.

description:
A great place to eat on a cold day and a empty tummy! 

There had been a slew of subpar businesses that occupied this space before Yuanbao Jiaozi opened up so I wasn't expecting a lot other than some hot food that would fill me up, but I was surprised. The place itself is very clean and minimally decorated with a big glass window where you can watch the kitchen staff make all the Jiaozi (I really enjoyed this part lol). 

My friend and I both ordered the Pork & Three Delicacies Dumpling Soup and the portions were big! I honestly don't find Jiaozi particularly special considering I grew up eating them and they kind of all taste the same to me, but these were tasty and the soup was comforting and partly a reason why I enjoyed this place so much. The only negative I have for this place is that it took quite some time for us to get our food even with only 2 other tables (who were already served) and a couple of take-out orders that came in while we were seated. 

TLDR; If you want inexpensive and yummy dumplings, come here--especially if you're starving because it's filling.
author: Anna L.

description:
=== Cliff Notes version === 

The food is good, but they need to take Customer Service and Logistics 101 (separate classes).

=== Long version ===

-- Prologue --
My dining companion and I got here right after 11 a.m. on a Sunday. Right off the bat there's a party of ~8 Chinese people ahead of us. The only waitress there puts together a few two-tops to accommodate them. The result was a big gap in the middle of the floor with two two-tops in awkward positions -- one right in front of the doors and the other angled in between a couple (Mr. and Ms. Quiet) and a guy sitting at the end of the big party.

-- Act I --
At this point we're standing in the opened doorway waiting for the waitress to seat us. In addition to the awkwardly positioned tables, there were two four-tops in decent places and one four-top in the back left corner. This one was so squeezed into the corner, it had room for only two chairs, both of which were side by side and facing the dumpling prep area.

After I told the waitress I had two in my party, she had the gall to offer me the table right in front of the doors. I said, "I'm not sitting right by the door." She looked confused then proceeded to another table to take their order. HELLO?!!!!

Another waitress finally arrived (she was late), and (surprise! surprise!) she had the gall to offer me the table with the chairs facing the dumpling prep area. I refused and told her that's a terrible place. So she offered me one of the decent tables. At this point I was exhausted by the idiocy of the waitstaff.

-- Act II --
While we looked at the menu, I kept my eye on whether they were going to move the awkwardly laid two-tops to fill in the gap on the floor. Well, they didn't. Two women came in and were sat at the table right in front of the doors. When the waitress took their order, she stood between their table and the doors. A customer was trying to come in to join his party which was already seated, but he couldn't. The waitresses looked like idiots when they realized this and scrambled to unlock the left door for him. 

The whole time we were there they never moved the other awkward table so customers could use it. Instead, they pushed it right against Mr. and Ms. Quiet's table which unnecessarily caused a woman and her child to sign up on the wait list. (And most of us there weren't going anywhere for a while.)

-- Act III --
When the party of 8 finally left, the waitresses re-arranged the tables and seated strangers together at two-tops. An older man who didn't want to sit with a random younger guy was lucky that Mr. and Ms. Quiet just left, so he moved to their table. At another two-top, an older woman spotted the empty table behind me, so she darted for it. But the waitress insisted she go back to the two-top and sit with a stranger. Seriously??

-- Epilogue --
I understand restaurants don't want to sit X people at a Y table where X is less than Y. But I've been to many restaurants that will do that anyway if it makes the most sense at the time. They get it. They get that they should accommodate the customers physically standing at the door rather than the party of five that might or might not appear in the next 15 minutes. Yeah, this place is small, and lots of people come here. This pain point is a result of their success. But they need to remember that for young businesses continued success comes from happy dining experiences, which is the sum of many things, not just good food. So if you force strangers to sit together or force customers to sit in bad places when there are other options, they might not come back. I'm certainly not holding my breath until the next time I go back because I'm not dying to return.

=== The numbers ===

* Food: 3.8 (We ordered the cucumber salad, fish/mushroom dumplings, and chicken/mushroom dumpling soup)
* Value (food and price): 4
* Table Service: 2.5 (No offers to refill our water until we were done eating despite the fact the waitresses were standing around a couple of times. In my book a "3"/average table service includes water refills.)
* Host Service: 0
* Ambiance: 2.5

Average: 2.56
Final star rating: 2 (because I can)
author: Opal L.

description:
I'd heard this place was new and crowded, but on a rainy sf night, they were half empty. They can run out of certain items, and they did run out of their specialty fish one. The shrimp dumplings, in soup, were bomb. The pork were just aite. PS if you want it in soup I believe they give you a couple dumplings less.

We also tried the beef noodles, which were just mediocre too. The place is clean and approachable, with a small menu that makes it easy to introduce people to this kind of cuisine. It was boyfriend's first time having pig ear, which were good!

Think I'm still loyal to King of Noodle.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I lived in Shanghai, China, for 6 years. I've been yearning to find a place like this in SF since moving to the city early 2017. I was transported to a real Chinese steamed dumpling house from the moment I walked into this place. Expect authentic, fresh produce, non-Westernized Chinese food. Their specialty is steamed dumplings. They do 5-6 other complementary dishes. Highly recommend:

-Beef noodle soup
-Celery & pork dumplings
-Shrimp & 3 delicacies dumplings
-Tofu skin salad 
-Cucumber salad
author: Alex B.

description:
Delicious dumplings with great service and a very cozy, interesting atmosphere! We came here as a group of six and were served very quickly for such a large amount of people in a fairly small shop. The side dishes and dumplings were fresh and delicious, and we could watch them made right in front of us. The servers were also very nice answering our questions about the dishes and offering recommendations.

I loved everything about this place, and would recommend the Pork and Three Delicacies dumplings, as well as the cucumber salad (which is good on its own and also makes a good dipping sauce for the dumplings as well).
author: Bellamy K.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. The selfish part of me wants to rate this place down so it doesn't become that popular place with the hour-long wait, because that's what I expect this place would be very soon.

We came here for a snack after a walk in the park. We arrived when they opened and were one of the three parties in the restaurant. The staff greeted us and gave us our choice of table. The venue was light-filled and spacious. A glass panel separated the clean, organized kitchen from the dining area, so you can see the chefs meticulously preparing your dumplings.

The service staff was extremely friendly. Sometimes I feel like I have to speak Chinese at a Chinese restaurant in order to get better service, but this comes at the cost of leaving my non-Chinese friends out of the conversations with the waiter. The staff here at Yuanbao Jiaozi was very courteous to us even though we spoke to them in English, and were treated just as well as the Mandarin/Cantonese-speaking parties next to us.

I was delighted by the small menu--no analysis paralysis! In my experience, places with small menus tend to have amazing food. They're confident that you'd be pleased by anything in their small food selection, and they're able to concentrate on mastering all their dishes.

My hunch was completely correct. We ordered two appetizers (about $6-7 each): the spicy beef tendon 麻辣牛筋 and shredded seaweed 海帶絲 (Chinese style, though they also offered the Japanese version of the dish). Though both were served cold in chili oil, they had very distinct flavors. The beef tendon's sauce included vinegar and tasted slightly sour, perfect for balancing out any excessively meaty taste. The seaweed salad tasted a bit musty like the ocean, which I loved.

We also ordered the pork & three delicacies dumplings 肉三鮮 ($8.99; not pictured because we just wolfed them down). The skin on these dumplings were thin yet chewy. They contained the perfect ratio of the filling. The minced meat was very tender, and tasted slightly herbal, maybe of Chinese five-spice? Overall, the food reminded me of my mom's cooking, one of the highest praises I can give.

I cannot wait to be back in the area just so I can come back to Yuanbao Jiaozi and try more of their dishes.
author: Yuki P.

description:
Leading by a hop, skip, and a jump, their beef noodle soup was the best I've had. Soup was flavorful, but not overpowering. Though, the noodles could've been a bit firmer for my preference. Dumplings are on par with most places, but they offer a shrimp and zucchini option that is a first for me.

What they NEED to improve on: their tofu salad was by far the worst I've had (it's one of my favorites at Szechuan restaurants). The texture of the tofu was akin to chewing on rubberbands, sauce was too sweet and not salty enough (albeit subjective), and the cilantro was old without a crispy stem. As I was chewing, I could feel and hear the sound the elasticity in the tofu. This. Should. Never. Happen.
author: Ben P.

description:
My parents and I couldn't decide where to eat for Sunday lunch, so we looked on Yelp and chose to try this new place. When we arrived, we found out that it's their soft opening right now. We were behind three other tables, and were seated in about 20 minutes. During the wait, we were observing the staff, and they all work so slowly. Most people were sitting idly at the tables on their phones, as if waiting for something. One even got tired of waiting and went up to the front to pay the bill. The people making the dumplings were so slow and forming them in an unnecessarily delicate way. The waitresses had clean tables empty for minutes before seating the next group on the list. However, it is their soft opening, so I understand that the restaurant is still developing efficient operations and workflow. 

Hot and Spicy Beef Tendon ($6.99) - so flavorful. The sauce was so good and I almost wanted to drink it - I didn't, but I did dip my dumplings into it! However, the portion is incredibly small for the price, especially compared to other restaurants that serve this dish.
Shredded Seaweed ($5.99) - also very good, with garlic and chili sprinkled on top. They asked if we wanted the Chinese or Japanese version (Japanese version is the seaweed salad that is sometimes sold at grocery stores/served in restaurants). We chose the Chinese version, and they're like seaweed "noodles", with a great texture (if overcooked, they're too soft). Also small portion for the price.
House Special Beef Noodles (I forgot price, but around $11-12?) - we got the spicy version, but we couldn't really tell because our appetizers were already spicy. It was very good, and the soup tasted a little herbal. The noodles were great as well, and it came with beef slices and cubes, some greens, and peanuts. We liked this. 
Shrimp and Three Delicacies Dumpling ($8.99) - shrimp, egg, and chive dumplings. They tasted good, great skin thickness, with a good amount of filling, and the shrimp was sweet (in a seafood way, not a sugar way) and cooked well. You can order dumplings on a plate (comes with 14) or in a soup (comes with 12). My dad was looking forward to a dumpling sauce, but they only had the standard soy sauce, chili sauce, and vinegars.

Card accepted only for purchases over $20. Their "Three Delicacies" should be clarified on the menu so that people don't constantly ask. The waitress told me that it is shrimp, egg, and chive. But then why is there a "Shrimp & Three Delicacies Dumpling"? Isn't that redundant? Also, it was clear that our group would be sharing the items that we ordered. All we were given were tiny little sauce plates. When we asked for something on which to eat the appetizers, we were given little bowls that are used in other places as sauce bowls (such as for hot pot). After the noodle soup came out, I asked for a bigger bowl, and the waitress seemed annoyed and gave me one (same type the appetizers came in). I didn't feel like service was slow during the meal, as we were just finishing up our appetizers when the noodle soup and dumplings came, and they gave us our check quickly after asking. The food overall was very tasty, but somewhat pricey for the small portions. Will come again after their grand opening to see if there are any changes.
author: Nicole M.

description:
We ordered 3 bowls of the beef noodle soup and then 3 different dumplings. The three types of dumplings we ordered were the shrimp & 3, the pork & 3, and the shrimp with zucchini. My favorite was the shrimp with zucchini. The dumplings are made right in front of you. You can see them send the dumplings to be cooked. The skin isn't too thick as well. The beef noodle soup was actually quite a lot of food in one bowl. They give you so much noodles and a good amount of beef. It was really good on a cold day. 
They're in their soft opening right now, which could mean they might have more variety later on. 
If you do plan to take some home since you might not finish the food, they do charge $0.25 per to-go box. That's why I took one star off. We ordered a lot to try and so we could take some home and have good leftovers. It does suck you have to pay for the boxes but oh well. Now I know to order less food so I can eat it all and not have to pay for the boxes.
author: Allyson L.

description:
So yummy!! They make everything by hand and the restaurant is small, so I've learned to only order take out. Otherwise, the wait time is loooong. Do try their pork and three delicacies dumpling (filled with pork, chives, egg, and vermicelli), as well as their fish and shiitake mushroom dumpling. So good! Their dumplings filled with celery has a strong celery taste (it's not as cooked down as most places), so I wouldn't recommend it if you don't like celery (I am, so I enjoyed it very much). I've also had their pig ears and cold cucumbers appetizers, which were great, too. So simple, yet so delicious! Lastly, I've had their spicy beef noodle soup which was NOT spicy! Would avoid unless you're really craving noodle soup-- in which case, may I suggest trying king of noodle down the street?

Overall, bad experience dining in. Would order to-go 100% every day if I could.
author: Leslie C.

description:
Have been here once and I have to say this place is way too overpriced because The filling of their dumplings are very less and tastes like a joke. 
Probably the only thing that can make their dumplings expensive is they make their dumplings more like an artwork.
author: Eric M.

description:
Such delicious dumplings, but my favorite thing here may actually be the pig ear! There can be quite the line for this place, but keep in mind that it moves pretty quickly (the small menu helps out with this).

Not actually amazed by their dumplings. You can order it steamed on their own or in a bowl of soup - Fried is +$1 - and have various sauces (soy sauce, red vinegar, chili oil) to play with. The pork and 3 delicacies was fine, but after eating a couple, you can tell that there's a lot of filler (egg) rather than meat. A little bit of a bummer. Shrimp and zucchini was delicious.

That being said, I would come back in a heartbeat. Really affordable ($8.99 for a plate of 14 dumplings!) and the pig ears were so perfect. Don't let the concept scare you (unless you're veg). They're thinly sliced and marinated in a sweet/spicy chili oil with garlic and onions and it's so umami and perfect. I promise!

Kudos to them for keeping it clean in here, and for the ladies in the window wrapping up dumplings at the speed of light. 

Minor ding for the 2 waitstaff - really polite and trying their best to accommodate, but clearly struggling to serve as hostess/waitress/busser/cleaner. It's a rough position :(
author: Colleen M.

description:
Really great, fresh tasting dumplings. The skins had a nice color and bite to them and you can watch them make it fresh.  The fillings I tried were Fish and Shiitake and the Chicken and Shiitake, but I would recommend the Fish since it was very flavorful as a dumpling in soup.  Would definitely fome back to try them all

However the seating is kind of limited.
author: Daniel C.

description: Authentic dumpling place. Highly recommend the pork and celery, pork and 3 delicacies (try the soup version) and mushroom and fish dumplings
author: Helen Y.

description:
Got here on a Saturday afternoon, saw a line outside while finding parking. As I went in, the wait wasn't too long but maybe because they're still new, the service was kind of slow. 

Very simple and clean menu, shop, and food. You can see the ladies making their fresh dumplings through the transparent glass as you wait for your food to come. 

Funny side story. On the menu for the dumpling side, they have the option of having it plain (steamed) or having the dumplings in soup. As we were waiting for our food to come, this dude next to us literally flagged and asked the waiter "so what are the differences between plain and in soup? By in soup do you mean the dumplings are in the soup or the soup are in the dumplings?" By that point, I couldn't help but to crack up inside. What kind of question is that? Lol maybe this guy got dumplings and XLB's (xiao long bao) mixed up cause... I've never had soup inside regular dumplings. 

But anyways....... ordered their shrimp and pork 3 delicacies dumping and their spicy beef noodle soup. 

Their beef noodle soup was on the lighter side. Their soup tasted something along the lines of light broth + beef stew/ brisket sauce + hint of white pepper. It came with 3 types of beef (seemingly): Thin slices of marinated beef, beef brisket, and beef cubes. They were all super tender and flavorful. 

I think if you like dumplings, the pork ones a standard staple. A good thickness for their handmade wraps, not too thick and not too thin, also good ratios with the fillings. 

For the shrimp dumplings, it was on the saltier side for me. Wasn't sure if it was due to the leek.. the shrimp or whatever it was in it. Also these weren't as filled compared to the pork ones and they were more watery, probably due to the moisture from either ingredient. 

Overall not bad for a new place on Irving. If you happen to be around and can find parking, get your dumpling fix on and don't forget to custom your own dumpling sauce! I like soy sauce + hot chili oil and flasks + red vinegar with the ratio being 3:2:1. Enjoy!
author: Aly C.

description:
Yuanbao Jiaozi makes their dumplings fresh to order and in plain view.

That said, I have a couple of concerns: The bathroom used by both diners and employees is only feet away from where the food is prepared. And, although I don't mind food prepares wearing no gloves or facemasks, shouldn't they wear hairnets?

At $6.99 the Marinated Beef is served cold and sliced relatively thick. At $4.99 their Cucumber Salad with cilantro and other seasonings was refreshing and complemented our dumplings.

At $8.99 the Shrimp & Three Delicacies Dumpling, 14 of them steamed on a plate couldn't taste fresher, mmm, mmm. And at $8.99 the Shitake Mushroom & Fish Dumplings were equally delicious.

Although they couldn't do it today their menu offers these dumplings three ways; steamed, in a soup, or pan-fried.

We'll be back!
author: Caesar A.

description: This has good potential. We had a variety of dumplings. Fish, chicken, pork. Sample the beef noodles. While everything was ok, thought it wasn't seasoned well. Little bland for my taste. The place is good enough for a steady crowd, menu is simple, and the presentation is done well. Especially with the old ladies in the display making dumpling like the famous Taiwanese chain.
author: Phillip K.

description:
Amidst the many establishments that sell dumplings... there has finally emerged one that I might consider the potential top dog: Yuanbao Jiaozi. 

Food:
I love their dumplings! You have a simple and concise menu of fillings to choose from. We ordered the Shiitake mushroom and fish dumplings as well as the shrimp and 3 delicacies. You have an additional option of having them in the soup base or simply on a plate. (Tip: If you op for the soup base, one order would suffice). When biting into the dumplings, the filling was nice and offered a pleasant bouncy texture. The skin on the dumplings were crafted very nicely had a chewy bite. 

Aside from dumplings, their appetizers were also very solid. We ordered the chili oil pig ear and chili oil beef tendon. Both had just the right amount of kick to them and boasted enough flavor to offset the delicate flavors of the dumplings. 

Ambiance: 
The place is really bright and vibrant with some appropriate wall decor. The paintings were not an eye sore and actually contributed to the atmosphere. Although a smaller space, I appreciate the detail of having a transparent glass to watch the workers make the dumplings. 

Service:
Would have been a 5 star review, but minus ~ .5 stars for the slower, less attentive service. In her defense, she was the only one taking orders for the space and it is technically still soft-opening. Hoping service will be more streamline in the future.
author: Tyler D.

description: Had their beef noodle soup... slices of beef though small portions for $11.  Dumplings was a bit dry and less flavorful than others down the street.  Dumplings were made fresh though
author: David H.

description: Literally my favorite restaurant of all time! The food is nothing too heavy but super fresh and delicious, and I especially love how you can watch the chefs wrap your dumplings from anywhere in the restaurant. The environment is super clean and intimate and I have never had a problem with an order--whenever there's a mistake (which is not often) they agree to fix it right away. My favorites are the mushroom and fish dumplings and their beef noodle soup. Their menu is quite small which means quality meals no matter what you order. Highly recommend, I would come here everyday if I could!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Yummy, delicious, fresh. Came here on a Monday night around 6:30pm and was seated right away. Simple menu, variety of dumplings, we got the beef noodle soup and the zucchini shrimp and fish shiitake dumplings- all were great. I liked the shrimp dumplings better but I'm biased, cause I like shrimp. 13 dumplings came in one $8.99 dumpling order, a very good deal to me. The noodle soup comes with plenty of noodles which is what I'm always looking for. 

One waitress keeping things running smoothly. I'll be back!
author: Alison L.

description:
DELICIOUS!!!!
Everything we had was fresh.    Service was great.
The table set up could need a reconfiguration.
author: Hannah L.

description:
Came here for a quick dinner, there was nothing quick about it. 

The place is fairly new and so are some of the staff they recently hired. Being new they don't know a thing to do as far a customer service.

We ordered and waited and waited. Some of the things came out slow because they literally make things after people order it. And then other things were slow because they forgot about it. 

The food is not bad, but after a few bites all the 8 dumplings taste about the same.
author: M C.

description:
Went on February 10 for their soft opening. This place offers a small menu of dumplings served three ways (your choice of regular boiled, with soup or pan fried) and an equally small menu of cold appetizers. Some dumpling options are chicken and mushroom, shrimp and veggies, celery and chicken, celery and pork, and the two we chose:

- Mushroom fish dumpling: This is their house special, according to our server, and we chose to have it just boiled. The wrap was on the thick side but had a nice chew. Definitely fresh tasting--you can see the workers making the dumplings to order in the glass-walled kitchen. The filling was tasty in a homemade sort of way. The fish and mushroom are chopped up small, and the seasoning is very mild. This one benefited from some chili in oil and vinegar. Shiitake mushrooms gave it a nice dose of umami. Overall, a decent dumpling that satisfies.

- Shrimp zucchini dumpling: We chose to get this one with soup, which is a clear broth with cilantro. Compared to the mushroom fish, this was less satisfying. The filling was chopped so finely that it was hard to tell it's shrimp. Pretty mild flavor as well--ate this one with chili and vinegar, too. Between the two dumpling orders and one appetizer, the two of us were full and had four dumplings left to take home. Decent value. 

- Spicy beef tendon: Average. Does a good job at whetting your appetite.

- Service: As to be expected for a first day, service was imperfect. The kitchen was pretty backed up, for which the servers were very apologetic, which was nice. We waited more than half an hour for the first plate of dumplings to come out, and then another 20 minutes for the second dish. This wasn't too bad in itself, but I was a little ticked off that a table that arrived and ordered after us was given their dish before us--the exact same dish that we ordered. Serving tables in the order they arrive seems pretty basic, but it's their first day so I try not to hold it against them. 

I'd give this place another chance and try some of the other dumplings, but I wouldn't exactly be running back here.
author: Alice L.

description: In town for the day and read the yelp reviews and decided to try it.  We arrived at opening so no wait.  I just don't give 5 star ratings as there is always a minor glitch preventing it.  Not this time.  This is the real deal.  I understand why there can be a wait, the place is tiny, but Holy Cow Batman, those are dumplings!
author: Paul S.

description: Solid dumpling joint. The hot and spicy beef tendon was excellent and full of flavor with mild heat, but tasty nonetheless. The shiitake and fish dumpling are the winner, and in broth it makes them extra soft.
author: Alex J.

description: The best dumplings restaurant for me so far. I'm a big fun of dumplings. I had been tried many dumplings place, this one was the best! The mushroom fish is juicy and flavorful. It will add more flavor if you dip it in the soy sauce+ chilly sauce( you can make it yourself). It's my favorite. Highly recommend the dumplings with soup, healthy! The mushroom chicken is a little of dry compare to mushroom and fish. But still good. Shrimp and three delicacies is my second favorite. There is chives eggs and shrimps. Very delicious!! Beef tendon appetizer is also a hit!
author: Grace L.

description:
These are some awesome dumplings. The menu is small, but everything I've had was fresh and flavorful. 

The dumpling skin was thin enough not to be chewy, but tough enough not to fall apart when you pick it up. A good balance that is and to find. The fillings are obviously fresh and well balanced. 

The beef noodle soup was excellent. The noodles tasted like they were just rolled. It also included certain cuts of meat that are shunned by most Americans but prized in other cuisines. I'm talking tongue and other organ meats :) 

All in all, they don't cut corners and it shows.
author: Tony L.

description: Asked the waitress a simple question regarding allergy information, and she refused to answer (in either English or Chinese). If you want dumplings, Bei Fang is a 30 second walk down Irving and the owner is MUCH nicer and friendlier. Also, Yuanbao seems to nearly only serve jiaozi (steamed dumplings), while Bei Fang serves jiaozi in addition to a variety of other Northern Chinese style dishes.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This dumpling place looked very promising but it was okay at best. The menu is rather limited, and the dumplings are good but not great. Service was excellent though, and pricing was decent for the sunset. 

Food: The seaweed salad was nicely seasoned and pretty generously portioned. I thought it was a nice touch that they offered "Chinese spicy style" or "Japanese non-spicy". The shrimp zucchini dumplings were pretty good, while the pork five spice dumplings were nothing too special- there were some chives but not enough for much flavor. I also saw some other tables order the beef noodle soup, which may be promising. I'm a little confused by the limited offerings of 5-6 appetizers, dumplings, and beef noodle soup. They're going to have to step up their game if they want to compete with Kingdom of Dumpling or Beifang style (better food, ridiculously good prices).

Interior: The interior is well lit and has a nice modern feel. If you like to eat at places with good decor, this might be a better choice than the dingier sunset spots (which admittedly have better food).

Service: Great service! Attentive waitresses who refilled water quickly. Food was brought out quickly.

Overall: Great ambiance, decent food but there's stiff competition in the sunset for dumplings!
author: Jackie T.

description:
Simple, authentic, great price, & delicious. 

This place mainly serves dumplings and then some appetizers.  The menu is small and simple but the dishes are done very well and really flavorful.  
I really liked the way they did the dumplings; fresh, flavorful and the skin had the perfect texture. 

I really recommend trying the dumplings in soup as well!  The broth was so simple but so fresh and tasty!

One thing, however, is that we ordered the "pork and three delicacies" dumplings but every once in awhile, found a piece of shrimp in the filling of those dumplings.  But I didn't specifically ask about if there was shrimp in it.  In case any of you have an allergy to shrimp, like I do, I recommend asking and letting your server know about it before hand.  

Overall, I had a great dining experience here.  The food hit the spot and was really good.
author: Daisy S.

description: Good food, but still some new restaurant service kinks to iron out to improve the experience. Al dente noodles in their flavorful beef soup and thin handmade dumpling wrappers with just the right chew. I'll be back to try more.
author: A L.

description:
I feel like by writing a review I'll be shooting myself in the foot. Instead of keeping this my little secret dumpling place I'll be forced to wait in lines of people looking for their latest fix. But alas, the news must be shared.

Fresh made to order dumplings in a small and clean restaurant. Service is friendly, food is delicious, and the price is on point. I've come here a number of times with my wife and have tried a variety of their dumplings, they've all been great.

Do yourself a favor and check this place out. Eat a dumpling or 20. Wish to yourself that they sold frozen dumplings to go. Order another 10, and promptly scarf those down as well.
author: Daniel G.

description:
First time giving a restaurant review on yelp which i think it is really worth of my time! Came here on Sunday night got seated right away. You can see the ladies making fresh dumplings through the glass. Simple menu with traditional Chinese dumplings. 

The service is great, their staffs are super friendly. They gave us some recommendations and explanation on dumplings and other food as well.  

You can choose the dumplings to be made in chicken soup or steamed. We ordered pork & three delicacies, mushroom & chicken, celery & pork dumplings and mushroom & fish in soup. The regular one has 14 dumplings and the one with soup has 12. I think they're really worth with just $8.99/order. We also ordered a beef noodles, the portion is big, ($10.99)soup and beef both taste really delicious.
author: Kai D.

description: This dumpling place is amazing！! The best dumpling place I ever tried in San Francisco. Thier dumplings are fresh and juicy since the restaurant made them instant after order was placed.  Their place is clean and bright and you can even see how the dumpling was made through their glass window. Price is absolutely inexpensive compared to any other restaurants at Irving street. Definitely will come back again for the amazing price and good food quality!!
author: Olivia W.

description:
This place is fantastic and not to be missed. Right as you walk in, you'll see the dumpling makers through their glass partition working on making all the different types of fresh dumplings. We tried the pork with 3 delicacies (which is pork, leek, egg, and shrimp), the green pepper and fish, mushroom and fish dumplings as well as the cucumber salad and marinated beef. It was SO good and so fresh. Perfectly light and seasoned and it's obvious they only use very fresh ingredients by the taste of all our dumpling fillings. Hope they keep up the fantastic work and quality after this soft opening! 

And serious kudos to their sole waitress who diligently buzzed around the room taking orders/bussing tables/ringing up checks/organizing the kitchen/cleaning nonstop. Super attentive and hardworking staff all together!
author: Cynthia S.

description: This place was very good and met my expectation. I ordered the beef noodle soup and also the pork & 3 delicacies. Noodle and the flavor of the brothe was very good and I really like the dumplings as well. I'm going to come back and try other things on the menu. The reason for four stars was because the waitresses were kind of slow and they weren't very attentive. I hope this place doesn't get too popular or else there's going to be long wait for table so I better go there before it gets too popular! But I also saw a lot takeouts so definitely an option too.
author: Wing C.

description: Solid place. Nice decor. Solid food. The beef noodle soup is good. The dumplings are good. You get a lot of dumplings for the money. Cash only under $20.
author: Karl K.

description:
Not that authentic Northeastern food from China. 

Averagely cooked dumplings. 

Very similar to the dumplings lots of northeastern people can cook.

Beef noodle soup lacks proper flavor.
author: Annie Y.

description: Wonderful beef noodle soup and delicious pork and cabbage dumplings. Reasonably priced and very delicious. I highly recommend this Restuarant.
author: Carlos M.

description: Wow this place is top notch for dumplings. They make the dumplings fresh in front of you and the people working there are real northerners. They have a good variety of unique dumplings you can choose from the menu. Their appetizers and beef noodle soup is also very tasty. Very good place to have lunch.
author: Kevin R.

description: New dumpling place on Irving. I got the mushroom and chicken dumplings $8.99 (you can get them fried for 1$ more) It's their soft opening so they didn't have that option so I got the regular ones. There's around 14 per order and they handmake all the dumplings in house!
author: Daniel S.

description: It's going to be my favorite dumplings restaurant! Fresh handmade dumplings are so delicious. I really like there homemade sauce. I also recommend their tender beef for appetizer. The table is very clean. You can also see the chefs making fresh dumplings from the window.
author: Fei F.

description:
3.5 Stars

We tried two (out of the seven) types of dumplings offered: Fish w/ Shiitake, and Shrimp. Both were well seasoned and packed with distinctive flavors. The skin is unusually thin, a change from the typical boiled dumpling. It has a nice texture and chewiness, though some may find it a bit tough, esp. when it gets cold. Enjoyed both dumplings overall.

The Beef Noodles were ok. We enjoyed the spiciness of the soup, however it was fairly typical.

As for the appetizers, we enjoyed the Beef Tendons, though it would have been better if there weren't so many small bits & pieces. The Tofu Skin Salad tended to be overly sweet.

Enjoyed the food overall, and would come back to they some of the other dumplings.
author: David W.

description:
Wow, just wow. Some of the freshest and tastiest dumplings that I have ever eaten. The flavors are really interesting and different that your normal dumpling restaurant. Instead of pork and napa or chicken and chive, you can try shitake and fish or shrimp and zucchini. Just some really interesting dumplings. We ordered pork and 3 delicacies,  which has chive and egg in it. The dumplings are made to order, so be patient. It is worth the wait. Sometimes things will sell out, just roll with it. The wrapper is thin and the meat inside was tender and juicy. Also tried the shrimp and zucchini,  which had nice pieces of juicy shrimp inside.
The beef noodle soup was really tasty too. The noodles cooked just right and the soup wasn't greasy. You also get different cuts of beef, so it was really good. Our small dishes were cucumbers, pig ear and tofu skin. The cucumbers could have used a bit more garlic and salt. Everything was good though, although the spicy oil sauce was pretty similar in all three dishes. 
Overall this place was a big hit with my family. I would only suggest to the owners that they should add noodles.and soup to all of the dumpling options because not everyone likes beef and there are no other noodle options for people. They also do not serve any type of drink as of yet.
Go before the lines start wrapping down the street.
author: Dom L.

description:
It's good, fresh, homey. 

But the dumplings themselves are a bit underseasoned. 

Like I would go here for a quick bite, but I wouldn't wait if there is a line.
author: Nathan N.

description:
I never had fish dumplings before so I ordered hesitantly but it was the star item. Amazing umami flavor contrasted with tangy, sharp green chili.
The only noodle soup in the menu (Beef noodle soup) was so good that my non-beef eating sister ate beef for the first time!
author: Food S.

description: Oh my! What a surprising place that we found when we were looking for a place to dine tonight.  This restaurant provides freshly wrapped dumplings that you can see thru their kitchen. They are not shy to show you the ingredients & the process of making your dumplings upon ordering. That has been proven to me that the kitchen is truly clean.  Initially we didn't intend to order more than we wanted but the waitress introduced us to try different types of dumplings that we could share among us. I was so full & contented but I certainly will come back to try the unique pork, zucchini & egg dumplings next time. I have to say that the pretty waitress Xiao Jiang is a great asset to the restaurant owner. I complimented the owner, Mr Ma for a well trained waitress and he gladly accepted it humbly. Btw. The whole place is clean AND it opens till 10 pm.
author: Wendy W.

description: Worth a try. It is made to order and has a good taste. Staff was friendly and place was clean. They could back off on the salt just a tad for some of the dumplings - which is why I didn't give them 5 stars.
author: Gordon M.

description: Handmade (I'm talking real dough, each dumpling rolled out, ingredients added then hand folded and crimped closed)one by one... really fresh, delicious dumplings! The dumplings were really good but the soup was too bland. We had to use a lot of chili oil/vinegar/soy sauce to make the broth more tasty. I would get just the dumplings next time. There were no pan fried dumplings or shrimp dumplings on the night we came here. As it turned out they put a lot of dumplings in the soup so we couldn't have shared an order of fried dumplings on top of the soup dumplings. It would have been way too much food. We wanted tea to drink but they only have water. There are definitely kinks to work out and I'm sure they will adjust their business plan accordingly as it is still a soft opening.
author: Kim B.

description: We came here during a cold summer evening. The food was comforting. We ordered shrimp and three delicacies dumpling, and the house special beef noodle. The beef in the noodle was very tender. The dumpling was fresh and delicious.
author: Shinta L.

description: Very yummy dumplings! Price is very reasonable for the large sized dumplings (comes with 14 and 12 in soups)! The only thing keeping me from coming back is how long it takes. They make the dumplings fresh to order so I understand the process but it took a while. We ordered two kinds of dumplings, one came out in 25 minutes then the other came out like 12 minutes later. Keep in mind the shop is small and there were about 4 other customers inside so I can't imagine the wait if there was more people.
author: Grace H.

description:
Best dumplings in sf freshly made to order. Clean
Kudos to young gal manning front of house all by herself!
author: Petri Y.

description: My go-to for dumplings. All of the dumplings, the tofu skin, and the beef noodle soup are amazing. Plus the kitchen where they make dumplings is glassed in so it's dinner with a show. Love this place!
author: Ted G.

description: Shrimp dumpling soup, beef noodle soup and tofu stick salad a must. Made with fresh ingredients.
author: Jeannie M.

description: Very tasty and affordable dumplings. The spicy beef tendon and cucumber salad are also very good. I come to this neighborhood in SF a lot and have been coming here religiously since the place opened. It's very good and very fast service. Getting a table during the day can be difficult but other than that I've been very happy with the food.
author: d b.

description: This tiny shop is a gem. I was so excited about the dumplings I forgot to take a photo before we ate them!  I especially liked the mushroom and fish dumpling even though we ordered several different kinds in addition to the noodle soup. I will definitely be back to try the ones that we didn't get to try this visit. Depending on what time you go the wait can be long but make sure you add your name to the waiting list which is inside at the counter.
author: L C.

description: Very nice and clean place. Great service. My favorite is shredded pig ear in a chili oil.
author: Sokunpich C.

description:
taste okay
filling in the dumpling is too little

really bad service
waitress impatient and impolite
author: 以欢

description: Had better frozen Jiaozi.  Had a long wait for the Jiaozi to come to the table...it wasn't even busy.
author: Ali L.

description: Loved this place. The food is just perfect. Loved the house noodle soup and jiaozi. The place feels nice and looks very clean. The watt is also very friendly.
author: Burim D.

description: I passed by this place today and saw its menustand outside the door, it said beef noodle soup in secret recipe that caught my eyes.  Well, I ordered it to-go.  I was so disappointed when I opened the containers.  There were only 3 tiny beef slices with several tiny beef tendons, cost $11.  Noodles were too soft and the broth was too light.  I tried so many beef noodle soup in the bay area, this was the worst experience ever.
author: Mei Y.

description: This is NOT a group spot. They're new and inefficient as fck, and they also don't give a fck that they're inefficient. Service is slow but the food is good. DO NOT go in a group. Dumplings are made to order, so yes they are incredibly fresh, and YES YOU WILL HAVE TO WAIT FOR THEM. I had the pork and 3 delicacies (without soup), an order of the beef noodle soup (while not the best, the broth was thin but umami, and noodz were solid), cucumber salad, and an order of pig ears. DUDE the pig ears are bomb, especially when you dip it in a little white vinegar. And the dumplings themselves... REALLY GOOD. You can watch my aunties make em through a window. At first it was nice watching them, then I felt sad but I was also hangry AF. Fresh dumplings are key. They have the dough for the skin premade and portioned out already, so when you order dumplings they break it out and pound it out then stuff it with the fillings. They were quite generous with the filling and I found one order left me content, seeing as I ordered other dishes as well. I'd go with one or two other ppl but that's it. DO NOT GO IN A GROUP. This spot is also tiny, with maybe only like 5 tables.
author: Susy C.

description: Bomb.com. Really fresh, delicious, and authentic. Great neighborhood dumpling place. I'm afraid it's gonna get too busy already!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Solid quality dumplings that are priced very reasonably at $8.99 and any order can be turned into a dumpling soup (seaweed broth is A+). The place itself is fairly small ~10 tables but things move fairly quickly. iTea is also close by if you want a quick boba before the dumps.
author: Eddie L.

description: If you're looking for freshly rolled dumplings this is the place! My takeout order was the celery and pork filling and it tasted so goooddd! The order included this vinegar sauce that was phenomenal. Only a little dip of the sauce needed. Highly recommend this place.
author: Amy T.

description: Very pleasantly surprised. I thought I have had enough different dumplings and noodles. But they beat my expectations
author: Ye Y.

description: Wow. This place has amazing northern Chinese cuisine. Very affordable, extremely tasty, and definitely authentic. You can watch the grandmothers make the food before you eat it! I thought the beef soup and pork with three delicacies dumplings were crazy good. Cucumber salad as well. Will definitely be back!
author: David B.

description: Decided to check this new joint out since it popped up on Yelp's hot n new. Came in a weekend and pretty close to closing so they were outta a lot of jiaozi on the menu. Friend and I decided to go with their niu rou mian and their pork jiaozi, both surprisingly good. Both waitresses explained the menu thoroughly and were very attentive. Definitely coming back to try their other jiaozi that wasn't available tonight.
author: Panchali S.

description: Spent 20 minutes waiting for someone to take my order. Waiters were happily serving 2 other tables who arrived later, but chose to absolutely ignore me. Have to leave. Waste of time.
author: Kirill A.

description: Halfway through the meal, the guy at the table next to us turned and said "I think this place has the best dumplings in the city right now." I hadn't thought about it yet, but I realized he was right.
author: Jordan F.

description: Dumplings are freshly made and the ingredients taste fresh as well. We were very disappointed that even though the menu says you can get it pan fried, they no longer do that. Beef noodle soup also gets sold out by 1pm on a Saturday so go early if you want to try that. Overall would recommend trying the pig ears appetizer and the shrimp or pork dumplings w/ 3 delicacies. Fish and mushroom dumplings were interesting since I haven't had that combo before. It is good if you are a fan of shitake mushrooms as the mushroom taste is quite overpowering.
author: Cindy L.

description: Tasty dumplings made fresh for you!  14 bite sized dumpling per order (maybe two bites for some people).  Beef noodle soup available but not on their limited menu.  Very friendly service!  The waitress informed me that the noodles were made in house.   Had the shiitake and chicken dumplings, cucumber salad, and bean curd sticks.  Plan to return for more dumplings and try the beef noodles.
author: R K.

description:
Their dumplings are pretty good but IMO the beef noodle soup is even better. The noodles are really good, and the soup is awesome.

Be careful because the place is a little small and they aren't the quickest with service, so if you go at peak times expect there to be a wait. Personally I think it's fine, just walk along Irving for a few blocks and come back..plus even if you don't want to do that, it's well worth the wait!
author: Nelson D.
